ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to understand the methods used in empirical social science papers; recent research on the gender wage gap, the impact of children, education, discrimination, and other factors that contribute to the dichotomy between men and women in the economy
I learned about labor economics in this course and factors that influence female labor force participation currently and in the past.

Excellent course that discusses a wide variety of topics with the economics of gender, from the stuff you expect, like gender-wage gap, more niche topics like how gender differences in education effect future earnings

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved the class, but I wish we had more class discussions rather than presentations. The information was so interesting and our discussions were engaging, and I wish there was more time for that!

Strengths: study questions force students to be engaged with the reading; periodical deadlines for the paper keep students in check Weaknesses: could have provided more resources for students struggling with R or Stata

The material was very interesting in this course and Professor Altonji is very engaged in the course and is well prepared for each class. Weaknesses would include a lack of feedback on presentations and weekly responses, so you didnt really know how to improve each week. In addition, doing the empirical analysis was very difficult and many of us didnt feel prepared to do this.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Very interesting and relevant topics
This class is a good introduction to labor economics. The readings are the best part of this course.

I would recommend this course to a student who has a mastery of R or Stata so that they wont feel overwhelmed by the final project. Even with Econometrics (Econ 117) the final project proved to be the most time consuming project Ive done- but it was rewarding, nonetheless.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially if you are interested in labor economics and the impact of gender on labor force participation and wages.
